label: LABEL
comment: A rdfs:comment

label: phenotype
description: A quality or combination of qualities of an organism determined by the interaction of its genetic makeup and environment that differentiates specific instances of a species from other instances of the same species.
comment: Existing definition from OGMS:0000023 already OBO-compliant. | Reasoning: Definition follows genus-differentia form with 'quality' as genus. Aligns with OGMS:0000023 definition and PATO quality concepts. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: stenohaline
description: A halophily preference in which an organism can only tolerate a narrow range of salinity concentrations and cannot survive significant changes in environmental salt levels.
comment: Stenohaline organisms have narrow salinity tolerance, contrasting with euryhaline organisms. | Quantitative values: Salinity Tolerance Range: < 5% variation from optimum (Source: PMID:22092493) | Reasoning: Distinguishes stenohaline from euryhaline organisms by narrow salinity tolerance range. | Parent class ID: PATO:0001655

label: hydrogenotrophic
description: A trophic type in which an organism uses molecular hydrogen as an electron donor for energy generation and carbon dioxide as the primary carbon source.
comment: Common in methanogenic archaea and some bacteria. | Reasoning: Definition specifies H2 as electron donor and CO2 fixation, characteristic of hydrogenotrophic metabolism. | Parent class ID: GO:0006091

label: photolithotrophic
description: A trophic type in which an organism uses light as the energy source and inorganic compounds as electron donors, typically with carbon dioxide as the primary carbon source.
comment: Found in cyanobacteria and some purple and green sulfur bacteria. | Reasoning: Combines phototrophy (light energy) with lithotrophy (inorganic electron donors) and autotrophy (CO2 fixation). | Parent class ID: GO:0006091

label: gram stain
description: A phenotype determined by the differential staining characteristics of bacterial cell walls when treated with Gram stain reagents, reflecting differences in cell wall structure and composition.
comment: Fundamental bacterial classification based on cell wall structure. | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes cell wall structure as the basis for Gram staining results. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: NaCl optimum
description: A phenotype that describes the specific concentration of sodium chloride at which a microorganism exhibits maximum growth rate and metabolic efficiency.
comment: Related to halophily preferences but specifically defines optimal concentration point. | Reasoning: Definition refined to follow genus-differentia form. No organism-specific values included. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: cell shape
description: A phenotype that describes the characteristic three-dimensional morphological form of a microbial cell, determined by cell wall structure, cytoskeletal elements, and environmental factors.
comment: Cell wall and cytoskeletal elements are key determinants of bacterial shape. | Reasoning: High-level phenotypic category serving as parent for specific shape terms. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: Methanogenesis
description: A metabolic process in which methane is produced as the primary end product through the reduction of carbon-containing compounds such as carbon dioxide, formate, methanol, or acetate, exclusively performed by methanogenic archaea under strictly anaerobic conditions.
comment: Temperature range 0-110°C spans psychrophilic to hyperthermophilic methanogens. | Quantitative values: Temperature Range: 0-110°C; Optimal Ph Range: 6.5-7.8 (Source: PMID:23645609) | Reasoning: Definition distinguishes methanogenesis by unique end product, specific substrates, and taxonomic restriction to archaea. | Parent class ID: GO:0008152

label: ellipsoidal
description: A cell shape in which an organism has an oval or ellipse-like morphology, elongated along one axis with rounded ends, intermediate between spherical and rod-shaped.
comment: Length-to-width ratio 1.5-3.0 distinguishes from cocci (ratio ~1.0) and elongated rods (ratio >3.0). | Quantitative values: Length To Width Ratio: 1.5-3.0; Length Range: 1.5-4.0 μm; Width Range: 0.8-1.5 μm (Source: PMID:24478428) | Reasoning: Definition provides clear geometric description. Length-to-width ratio quantifies the elongation. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: Fermentation
description: A metabolic process that generates energy through the oxidation of organic compounds without using an external electron acceptor, using organic molecules as both electron donors and final electron acceptors.
comment: Key distinction from respiration is lack of external electron acceptor. | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes internal electron cycling characteristic of fermentation, distinguishing from respiration with external acceptors. | Parent class ID: GO:0045333

label: axially filamented
description: A motility phenotype in which an organism possesses axial filaments (endoflagella) located in the periplasmic space between the cell wall and outer membrane, enabling corkscrew-like movement.
comment: Characteristic of spirochetes. Axial filaments provide distinctive motility mechanism. | Reasoning: Definition specifies unique periplasmic location of flagella, characteristic of spirochetes. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000708

label: gram negative
description: A gram stain result in which bacteria do not retain crystal violet dye and appear pink or red after staining, indicating a thin peptidoglycan layer and presence of an outer membrane.
comment: Thin peptidoglycan layer and outer membrane are defining structural features. | Reasoning: Definition specifies staining result and underlying cell wall structure characteristics. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: pH tolerance
description: A phenotype describing the ability of an organism to survive exposure to pH values outside its optimal growth range without sustaining lethal damage.
comment: Distinct from pH growth preference which defines optimal conditions. | Reasoning: Definition distinguishes tolerance (survival) from optimal growth preference. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: obligately alkaphilic
description: A pH growth preference in which an organism requires alkaline conditions (typically pH above 8.5) for growth and cannot grow at neutral or acidic pH.
comment: Obligate nature means inability to grow at neutral pH, unlike facultative forms. | Quantitative values: Optimal Ph Range: pH 9.0-11.0; Growth Ph Limit: pH 8.5 (Source: PMID:17223624) | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes obligate requirement for high pH, distinguishing from facultative alkaliphiles. | Parent class ID: PATO:0001842

label: spiral shaped
description: A cell shape in which an organism has a three-dimensional spiral or helical morphology with regular coiling along its longitudinal axis.
comment: Found in spirochetes and spirilla. Distinct from simple curved shapes. | Reasoning: Definition describes helical geometry characteristic of spirochetes and spirilla. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: gram variable
description: A gram stain result in which bacteria from the same culture show both gram-positive and gram-negative staining characteristics, often due to age of culture or cell wall degradation.
comment: Often seen in older cultures or with certain bacteria like Gardnerella. | Reasoning: Definition explains variable staining within a population and common causes. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: GC content
description: A quality describing the percentage of guanine and cytosine nucleotides in genomic DNA, calculated as the ratio of GC base pairs to total base pairs.
comment: GC content varies widely across species (25-75%) and is taxonomically informative. | Reasoning: Definition specifies calculation method and components. Important taxonomic and evolutionary marker. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: crescent shaped
description: A cell shape in which an organism has a curved, crescent or comma-like morphology with one axis of curvature.
comment: Characteristic shape of Vibrio species and some other curved bacteria. | Reasoning: Definition describes characteristic curved geometry. Typical of Vibrio and related genera. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: culture temperature observation
description: An observation that records the temperature at which a microbial culture is maintained during laboratory cultivation or experimental conditions.
comment: Distinct from optimum temperature observation which measures growth optima. | Reasoning: Definition specifies observation context (culture conditions) and measurement type (temperature). | Parent class ID: OBI:0000011

label: nutrient adaptation
description: A trophic type describing an organism's physiological and metabolic adaptations to specific nutrient availability levels in its environment.
comment: Parent class for oligotrophic, copiotrophic, and other nutrient-related adaptations. | Reasoning: High-level category for oligotrophic, copiotrophic, and related adaptations. | Parent class ID: GO:0006091

label: optimum temperature observation
description: An observation that identifies the temperature at which a microorganism exhibits maximum growth rate or metabolic activity.
comment: Measures optimal growth temperature, distinct from culture temperature. | Reasoning: Definition specifies observation of optimal conditions for growth or metabolism. | Parent class ID: OBI:0000011

label: pH range (cellular homeostasis)
description: A phenotype describing the span of hydrogen ion concentrations within which a microorganism can maintain cellular homeostasis and sustain growth.
comment: Defines functional range for homeostasis, not just tolerance limits. | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes homeostatic capability across pH range rather than single optimum. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: ovoid shaped
description: A cell shape in which an organism has an egg-like or oval morphology, rounded at both ends with one end often slightly broader than the other.
comment: Similar to ellipsoidal but often with slight asymmetry. | Reasoning: Definition describes egg-like geometry, distinguishing from ellipsoidal by asymmetry. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: diplococcus shaped
description: A cell shape arrangement in which spherical cells remain attached in pairs following cell division, forming characteristic doublets.
comment: Characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria species. | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes paired arrangement of cocci as distinguishing feature. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: filament shaped
description: A cell shape in which an organism forms elongated, thread-like structures composed of cells remaining attached end-to-end after division.
comment: Common in actinobacteria and some cyanobacteria. | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes linear chain formation and elongated thread-like morphology. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: microbe
description: A material entity consisting of an organism or virus that is too small to be viewed by the unaided eye, typically requiring microscopy for observation.
comment: METPO primarily concerned with bacteria and archaea, including giant bacteria like Thiomargarita. | Reasoning: Definition based on size criterion and microscopy requirement. Uses OHMI definition. | Parent class ID: BFO:0000040

label: chemoautolithotrophic
description: A trophic type in which an organism uses chemical oxidation of inorganic compounds as the energy source and carbon dioxide as the primary carbon source for biosynthesis.
comment: Common in nitrifying bacteria and sulfur-oxidizing bacteria. | Reasoning: Combines chemotrophy (chemical energy), lithotrophy (inorganic electron donors), and autotrophy (CO2 fixation). | Parent class ID: GO:0006091

label: lithotrophic
description: A trophic type in which an organism uses inorganic compounds as electron donors for energy generation.
comment: Parent category for various lithotrophs using different inorganic substrates. | Reasoning: Definition emphasizes inorganic electron donors as distinguishing feature. | Parent class ID: GO:0006091

label: rod shaped
description: A cell shape in which an organism has an elongated, cylindrical morphology with relatively straight sides and rounded or flat ends.
comment: Also known as bacillus shape. Very common in bacteria. | Reasoning: Standard bacillus morphology description. Common bacterial shape. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000052

label: trophic type
description: A phenotype describing how an organism obtains carbon and energy for growth and metabolism.
comment: Fundamental classification of nutritional strategies. | Reasoning: High-level category defining nutritional strategies. Parent for autotrophy, heterotrophy, etc. | Parent class ID: PATO:0000001

label: methanotrophic
description: A trophic type in which an organism uses methane as the primary carbon and energy source through oxidation of methane to carbon dioxide.
comment: Important in methane cycle. Found in both aerobic and anaerobic methanotrophs. | Reasoning: Definition specifies methane as both carbon and energy source, distinguishing methanotrophs. | Parent class ID: GO:0006091

label: photoheterotrophic
description: A trophic type in which an organism uses light as the energy source and organic compounds as the primary carbon source for biosynthesis.
comment: Found in purple non-sulfur bacteria and some green non-sulfur bacteria. | Reasoning: Combines phototrophy (light energy) with heterotrophy (organic carbon). | Parent class ID: GO:0006091
